unnormalised: Chaos reigned supreme at Priya's wedding, all thanks to some "flexible" scheduling. The sangeet, initially slated for 7 PM sharp on 10/11/2024, magically morphed into a "late-night jam session" starting around 9:30 PM-ish. Apparently, her cousin, who promised to be the DJ, got stuck in Bangalore traffic.
normalised: Chaos reigned supreme at Priya's wedding, all thanks to some "flexible" scheduling. The sangeet, initially slated for seven P M sharp on tenth november two thousand and twenty four, magically morphed into a "late-night jam session" starting around nine thirty P M-ish. Apparently, her cousin, who promised to be the D-J, got stuck in Bangalore traffic.

unnormalised: The wedding day itself, 12/11/2024, began with the baraat...eventually. Supposed to kick off at 10 AM, Rakesh, the groom, finally arrived at 12:30 PM, blaming the "auspicious time" calculations that somehow shifted by 2.5 hours. Let's just say, the pandit was not amused.
normalised: The wedding day itself, twelfth november two thousand and twenty four, began with the baraat...eventually. Supposed to kick off at ten A M, Rakesh, the groom, finally arrived at twelve thirty P M, blaming the "auspicious time" calculations that somehow shifted by two point five hours. Let's just say, the pandit was not amused.

unnormalised: Lunch was another adventure. With the ceremony dragging on, the 1 PM buffet decided to make a cameo appearance closer to 3 PM. By then, half the guests were either asleep or raiding the dessert counter like it was the last Diwali sale. Someone even started a rumour about the "late-lunch discount."
normalised: Lunch was another adventure. With the ceremony dragging on, the one P M buffet decided to make a cameo appearance closer to three P M. By then, half the guests were either asleep or raiding the dessert counter like it was the last Diwali sale. Someone even started a rumour about the "late-lunch discount."

unnormalised: And the reception? Oh, the reception. Originally envisioned as a sophisticated 8 PM affair, it was more like a "post-ceremony-we're-starving" gathering at 10:45 PM. The only thing on schedule was the bride and groom's exhaustion.
normalised: And the reception? Oh, the reception. Originally envisioned as a sophisticated eight P M affair, it was more like a "post-ceremony-we're-starving" gathering at ten forty five P M. The only thing on schedule was the bride and groom's exhaustion.

unnormalised: Moral of the story? Indian Standard Time is less of a time zone and more of a suggestion. Next time, just tell everyone the event starts "sometime around whenever" and call it a day. Save yourselves the stress, and maybe hire a fortune teller instead of a wedding planner.
normalised: Moral of the story? Indian Standard Time is less of a time zone and more of a suggestion. Next time, just tell everyone the event starts "sometime around whenever" and call it a day. Save yourselves the stress, and maybe hire a fortune teller instead of a wedding planner.
